items.title: Trump says Russia's Vladimir Putin "let me down" on Ukraine
items.standfirst: President Trump is on his way back to the U.S. after a state visit to the U.K. During a news conference with Prime Minister Keir Starmer, he was asked about the war in Ukraine and specifically, Russian President Vladimir Putin. CBS News White House reporter Willie James Inman has more.
items.content: President Trump is on his way back to the U.S. after a state visit to the U.K. During a news conference with Prime Minister Keir Starmer, he was asked about the war in Ukraine and specifically, Russian President Vladimir Putin. CBS News White House reporter Willie James Inman has more.

items.title: Trump tells Britain to ‘call out the military’ to control its borders
items.standfirst: US president ends second state visit with warning that illegal migration could destroy the UK Donald Trump has told Britain it should “call out the military” to control its borders during a tightly controlled summit in which Keir Starmer ducked major flashpoints with the US president.During a potentially difficult two-day state visit for the government, Trump has for the most part avoided exploiting tensions, although he described the UK’s plan to recognise a Palestinian state as “one of our few disagreements”. Continue reading...
items.content: US president ends second state visit with warning that illegal migration could destroy the UK Donald Trump has told Britain it should “call out the military” to control its borders during a tightly controlled summit in which Keir Starmer ducked major flashpoints with the US president.During a potentially difficult two-day state visit for the government, Trump has for the most part avoided exploiting tensions, although he described the UK’s plan to recognise a Palestinian state as “one of our few disagreements”. Continue reading...

items.title: UK preparing to recognise Palestinian state as early as Friday
items.standfirst: Move comes after Israel fails to meet UK conditions that would have postponed stepThe UK is preparing to recognise the state of Palestine as early as Friday, after Israel failed to meet conditions that would have postponed the historic step, including a ceasefire in Gaza.Keir Starmer insisted the timing of the UK announcement had nothing to do with Donald Trump’s visit, even though the US president said at a press conference that he disagreed with Britain’s decision, without elaborating. Continue reading...
items.content: Move comes after Israel fails to meet UK conditions that would have postponed stepThe UK is preparing to recognise the state of Palestine as early as Friday, after Israel failed to meet conditions that would have postponed the historic step, including a ceasefire in Gaza.Keir Starmer insisted the timing of the UK announcement had nothing to do with Donald Trump’s visit, even though the US president said at a press conference that he disagreed with Britain’s decision, without elaborating. Continue reading...

items.title: Donald Trump, Keir Starmer and their vision on ongoing conflicts
items.standfirst: During a joint press conference, US President Donald Trump and UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer addressed multiple international conflicts. They highlighted differing perspectives on Gaza and Ukraine, with Trump openly disagreeing with Russian President Vladimir Putin’s actions. The leaders outlined their approaches while acknowledging contrasting views on key global issues. FRANCE 24's Douglas Herbert has more on the issue.
items.content: During a joint press conference, US President Donald Trump and UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer addressed multiple international conflicts. They highlighted differing perspectives on Gaza and Ukraine, with Trump openly disagreeing with Russian President Vladimir Putin’s actions. The leaders outlined their approaches while acknowledging contrasting views on key global issues. FRANCE 24's Douglas Herbert has more on the issue.

items.title: Trump Says US Is Close to a TikTok Deal With China
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump says the US is close to making a deal for TikTok with China. Trump says it would be done “in conjunction with China” and that the US is getting “a ‘fee plus’ for just making the deal," He spoke at a press conference alongside British Prime Minister Keir Starmer. (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: President Donald Trump says the US is close to making a deal for TikTok with China. Trump says it would be done “in conjunction with China” and that the US is getting “a ‘fee plus’ for just making the deal," He spoke at a press conference alongside British Prime Minister Keir Starmer. (Source: Bloomberg)

items.content: The York County, Pennsylvania, community is mourning three police officers who were killed in a shooting on Wednesday. Two others were wounded. CBS News correspondent Tom Hanson reports.

items.title: WATCH: Pennsylvania officials give update on shooting that left 3 police officers dead
items.standfirst: Three police officers were fatally shot and two wounded Wednesday in southern Pennsylvania, and the shooter was killed by police, authorities said. It was one of the deadliest days for Pennsylvania police this century.
items.content: Three police officers were fatally shot and two wounded Wednesday in southern Pennsylvania, and the shooter was killed by police, authorities said. It was one of the deadliest days for Pennsylvania police this century.

items.title: FTC Sues Ticketmaster, Alleging Illegal Coordination With Brokers and Bait-and-Switch Pricing

The complaint alleges that…
items.content: The Federal Trade Commission and seven states sued Ticketmaster and its parent company Live Nation Entertainment Thursday (Sept. 18), alleging that they illegally sold event tickets acquired by brokers and deceived consumers and artists about prices and policies. items.title: FTC accuses Live Nation, Ticketmaster of illegally reselling tickets
items.standfirst: Regulators allege Ticketmaster used deceptive pricing and sales tactics, costing consumers billions of dollars.
items.content: Regulators allege Ticketmaster used deceptive pricing and sales tactics, costing consumers billions of dollars.

items.title: Live Nation and Ticketmaster accused of allowing ticket brokers to rake in millions from resales
items.standfirst: FTC and seven states file lawsuit claiming resellers’ violations of ticket purchasing limits were ignoredThe US Federal Trade Commission and seven states accused Live Nation and its ticketing arm Ticketmaster of costing fans millions of dollars by tacitly allowing ticket brokers to scoop concert tickets and sell them at a significant markup, the agency said on Thursday.The lawsuit deepens Ticketmaster’s legal woes, which began after its botched 2022 sale of tickets to Swift’s much-hyped Eras tour. Continue reading...
items.content: FTC and seven states file lawsuit claiming resellers’ violations of ticket purchasing limits were ignoredThe US Federal Trade Commission and seven states accused Live Nation and its ticketing arm Ticketmaster of costing fans millions of dollars by tacitly allowing ticket brokers to scoop concert tickets and sell them at a significant markup, the agency said on Thursday.The lawsuit deepens Ticketmaster’s legal woes, which began after its botched 2022 sale of tickets to Swift’s much-hyped Eras tour. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The FTC and seven states sued Ticketmaster and Live Nation.
They allege illegal ticket resale tactics and deceptive pricing.
The lawsuit claims Ticketmaster allowed brokers to profit from resales.
The FTC accuses them of costing consumers billions of dollars.
The lawsuit follows issues with the 2022 Taylor Swift ticket sales.

items.title: First migrant deported to France under 'one in one out' deal
items.standfirst: The man was removed on Thursday under the "one in, one out" agreement and has arrived in Paris.
items.content: The man was removed on Thursday under the "one in, one out" agreement and has arrived in Paris.

items.title: First migrant deported under the UK's 'one in, one out' deal with France
items.standfirst: The first undocumented migrant has been deported from the UK to France on Thursday as part of an asylum deal that London hopes will deter small boats from crossing the English Channel. The British government hailed the move as "an important first step to securing our borders".
items.content: The first undocumented migrant has been deported from the UK to France on Thursday as part of an asylum deal that London hopes will deter small boats from crossing the English Channel. The British government hailed the move as "an important first step to securing our borders".

items.title: First person removed to France under ‘one in, one out’ asylum deal, says UK
items.standfirst: Agreement reached with France allows for removal of asylum seekers who arrive on small boatsThe first Channel migrant has been deported to France under the controversial one in, one out deal, the Home Office has confirmed.The home secretary, Shabana Mahmood, said: “This is an important first step to securing our borders. It sends a message to people crossing in small boats: if you enter the UK illegally, we will seek to remove you. Continue reading...
items.content: Agreement reached with France allows for removal of asylum seekers who arrive on small boatsThe first Channel migrant has been deported to France under the controversial one in, one out deal, the Home Office has confirmed.The home secretary, Shabana Mahmood, said: “This is an important first step to securing our borders. It sends a message to people crossing in small boats: if you enter the UK illegally, we will seek to remove you. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The first undocumented migrant was deported from the UK to France.
This deportation was part of the "one in, one out" agreement.
The agreement aims to deter small boat crossings of the English Channel.
The UK government hailed the move as a step to secure borders.
The deported individual arrived in Paris on Thursday.

items.title: CDC panel changes measles, mumps, rubella, varicella vaccine recommendation
items.standfirst: The Centers for Disease Control's vaccine committee voted Thursday to change its recommendation for the combined measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (MMRV) vaccine. CBS News medical contributor Dr. Céline Gounder breaks down the change.
items.content: The Centers for Disease Control's vaccine committee voted Thursday to change its recommendation for the combined measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (MMRV) vaccine. CBS News medical contributor Dr. Céline Gounder breaks down the change.

items.title: CDC's vaccine advisory panel votes on measles shot

items.title: US vaccine panel votes against use of combined measles shot in children under 4
Johns Hopkins doctor says majority of RFK Jr.'s vaccine panel is not qualified
items.standfirst: The Centers for Disease Control's vaccine advisory panel is meeting Thursday and Friday to decide whether to change recommendations for vaccinations. The meeting comes after Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. fired the CDC's director last month and replaced the entire vaccine advisory panel with his allies. Dr. Amesh Adalja from the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security joins CBS News to discuss.
items.content: The Centers for Disease Control's vaccine advisory panel is meeting Thursday and Friday to decide whether to change recommendations for vaccinations. The meeting comes after Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. fired the CDC's director last month and replaced the entire vaccine advisory panel with his allies. Dr. Amesh Adalja from the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security joins CBS News to discuss.

ai_summary: The CDC panel changed its recommendation for the MMRV vaccine.
The panel discussed and voted on hepatitis B and MMRV vaccines.
A US vaccine panel voted against using the combined measles shot.
The meeting followed the firing of the CDC director.
A Johns Hopkins doctor questioned the vaccine panel's qualifications.

clusters.title: Police fire tear gas at protesters during day of strikes in France

items.standfirst: Hundreds of thousands of people have taken part in anti-austerity protests and strikes in France.
items.content: Hundreds of thousands of people have taken part in anti-austerity protests and strikes in France.

items.title: Anti-austerity strikes and protests rock France, pressure Macron
items.standfirst: Massive anti-austerity protests and labour strikes were held across France on Thursday, in a show of anger over President Emmanuel Macron's austerity policies. Organisers said one million people took part in the strikes and protests, while the French authorities estimated that there were 500,000 protesters.
items.content: Massive anti-austerity protests and labour strikes were held across France on Thursday, in a show of anger over President Emmanuel Macron's austerity policies. Organisers said one million people took part in the strikes and protests, while the French authorities estimated that there were 500,000 protesters.

ai_summary: Hundreds of thousands protested and went on strike in France.
Protests were against President Macron's austerity policies.
Organizers estimated one million people participated in the strikes.
French authorities estimated 500,000 protesters.
The protests and strikes occurred across France.

clusters.title: Democrats Call for FCC Chair to Resign Over Role in Kimmel Ouster
clusters.neutral_headline: Democrats Call for FCC Chair to Resign Over Role in Kimmel Ouster

items.title: Democrats Call for FCC Chair to Resign Over Role in Kimmel Ouster
Obama denounces White House after Kimmel’s suspension
items.standfirst: Key Democrats are now calling for FCC Chair Brendan Carr to resign.
items.content: Barack Obama on Thursday condemned the Trump administration for its actions in the lead-up to Disney’s suspension of Jimmy Kimmel’s late-night comedy show, furthering the former president’s foray into the charged political climate in the wake of Charlie Kirk’s killing. “After years of complaining about cancel culture, the current administration has taken it to a new and dangerous level by routinely threatening regulatory action against media companies unless they muzzle or fire reporters and commentators it doesn’t like,” Obama wrote in a post on X on Thursday morning, about 15 hours after Disney announced it was suspending Kimmel. The comedian came under fire from White House officials for comments he made during a Monday broadcast of his show that appeared to align Kirk's suspected killer with the MAGA movement. Democrats have panned the comedian’s suspension, which came after Federal Communications Commission Chair Brendan Carr threatened consequences if the network failed to take action against the comedian in a Wednesday podcast with conservative commentator Benny Johnson. “We can do this the easy way or the hard way,” Carr told Johnson, threatening “additional work for the FCC.”Key Democrats, including Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer and House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries, are now calling for the FCC chair's resignation. “This is precisely the kind of government coercion that the First Amendment was designed to prevent — and media companies need to start standing up rather than capitulating to it,” Obama wrote, linking to a New York Times report that detailed the Washington Post’s firing of Karen Attiah, a columnist who said she was let go for her social media activity following Kirk’s killing. The FCC did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Obama’s comments. White House spokesperson Abigail Jackson told POLITICO that the notion of government encroaching on free speech had no involvement in Kimmel's suspension, but was the result of a decision by a private company. "Low-ratings loser Jimmy Kimmel is free to spew whatever bad jokes he wants, but a private company is under no obligation to provide him a platform to do so," she said in a statement. At an event in Pennsylvania on Tuesday, Obama himself mourned the loss of the Turning Point USA founder while making it clear that he disagrees with much of what Kirk stood for. And he faulted the current administration for the bleak state of American political discourse. “When I hear not just our current president, but his aides, who have a history of calling political opponents vermin, enemies who need to be targeted, that speaks to a broader problem that we have right now,” Obama said.

ai_summary: Democrats are calling for FCC Chair Brendan Carr to resign.
The calls for resignation are related to the Kimmel suspension.
The suspension of Kimmel's show is under scrutiny.
Obama denounced the White House after the suspension.
The FCC chair is facing pressure from Democrats.

items.standfirst: Israel’s Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich said a business plan for developing Gaza was on President Trump’s desk, adding, “We've done the demolition phase, which is always the first phase of urban renewal."
items.content: Israel’s Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich said a business plan for developing Gaza was on President Trump’s desk, adding, “We've done the demolition phase, which is always the first phase of urban renewal."

ai_summary: An Israeli minister said Gaza could be a "real estate bonanza".
The minister is Bezalel Smotrich.
A business plan for Gaza was sent to the US president.
Smotrich said the demolition phase is complete.
He described the destruction as an urban renewal opportunity.

clusters.title: The Indian state fighting rise in cases of rare 'brain-eating' disease
clusters.neutral_headline: Kerala Faces Rise in Rare Brain-Eating Disease Cases

items.title: The Indian state fighting rise in cases of rare 'brain-eating' disease
items.standfirst: Kerala is facing a serious public health challenge as it's seen a surge in cases of a "brain-eating" disease which has caused 19 deaths.
items.content: Kerala is facing a serious public health challenge as it's seen a surge in cases of a "brain-eating" disease which has caused 19 deaths.

items.title: Battling a rare brain-eating disease in an Indian state
items.standfirst: In Kerala this year, more than 70 people have been diagnosed and 19 have died from the brain-eating amoeba.
items.content: In Kerala this year, more than 70 people have been diagnosed and 19 have died from the brain-eating amoeba.

ai_summary: Kerala, India, is experiencing a surge in cases of a rare "brain-eating" disease.
The disease has caused 19 deaths in the Indian state of Kerala this year.
More than 70 people have been diagnosed with the disease in Kerala.
The disease is caused by a brain-eating amoeba.
The public health challenge is significant for the Indian state.

clusters.title: Tests show Navalny was poisoned in jail, his widow says
clusters.neutral_headline: Tests Show Navalny Was Poisoned, His Widow Says

items.title: Tests show Navalny was poisoned in jail, his widow says
items.standfirst: Yulia Navalnaya is urging the two laboratories she says found her husband was poisoned to release their findings.
items.content: Yulia Navalnaya is urging the two laboratories she says found her husband was poisoned to release their findings.

items.title: Lab tests show Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny was poisoned, his wife says
items.standfirst: Tests by two foreign laboratories show that Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny was poisoned before he died in an Arctic penal colony last year, his wife said Wednesday
items.content: Tests by two foreign laboratories show that Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny was poisoned before he died in an Arctic penal colony last year, his wife said Wednesday

ai_summary: Yulia Navalnaya stated that tests showed her husband was poisoned.
Two foreign laboratories conducted the tests on Alexei Navalny.
Alexei Navalny died in an Arctic penal colony last year.
Yulia Navalnaya is urging the release of the lab findings.
The tests were conducted before Navalny's death.

clusters.title: Hundreds of Machu Picchu tourists stranded
clusters.neutral_headline: Tourists Stranded Near Machu Picchu Due to Protest

items.title: Hundreds of Machu Picchu tourists stranded
items.standfirst: Hundreds of tourists have been left stranded near Peru's ancient Inca citadel of Machu Picchu after rail services were suspended because protesters blocked the route with rocks.
items.content: Hundreds of tourists have been left stranded near Peru's ancient Inca citadel of Machu Picchu after rail services were suspended because protesters blocked the route with rocks.

items.title: Rocks on train tracks strand 900 Machu Picchu tourists amid protest
items.standfirst: About 1,400 visitors were evacuated but hundreds were left stuck because of action linked to bus contract dispute, say Peru authoritiesAt least 900 tourists were stranded near the ancient Inca citadel of Machu Picchu on Tuesday, Peru’s tourism minister said, after a passenger train service was suspended due to a protest.PeruRail said service was suspended on Monday because the route in Peru’s mountainous Cusco region had been blocked by “rocks of various sizes” as residents clashed with authorities and bus companies. PeruRail’s local unit also said “third parties” had excavated part of its rail route, which affected the track’s stability and slowed down the evacuation of tourists. Continue reading...
items.content: About 1,400 visitors were evacuated but hundreds were left stuck because of action linked to bus contract dispute, say Peru authoritiesAt least 900 tourists were stranded near the ancient Inca citadel of Machu Picchu on Tuesday, Peru’s tourism minister said, after a passenger train service was suspended due to a protest.PeruRail said service was suspended on Monday because the route in Peru’s mountainous Cusco region had been blocked by “rocks of various sizes” as residents clashed with authorities and bus companies. PeruRail’s local unit also said “third parties” had excavated part of its rail route, which affected the track’s stability and slowed down the evacuation of tourists. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Hundreds of tourists are stranded near Machu Picchu due to rail suspension.
Protesters blocked the rail route with rocks, causing the suspension.
Approximately 900 tourists were stranded due to the protest action.
Authorities evacuated about 1,400 visitors from the area.
The protest is linked to a dispute over a bus contract.
